SkillScenario: Coach employee to be on time for meetings
TargetStrategies:
Address it early and privately (don’t let it linger).

Be factual, not emotional (state what you observed).

Explain impact (on the team, workflow, credibility).

Invite their perspective (listen before judging).

Clarify expectations (what “on time” means).

Collaborate on solutions (remove barriers).

Confirm commitment (clear next steps).

Follow up (signal accountability, not punishment).
TargetLanguage:
“I'd like to talk briefly about meeting start times.”

“I’ve noticed you’ve arrived a few minutes late to several meetings.”

“I want to share this early so it doesn’t become a bigger issue.”

“When meetings start late, it affects the whole team.”

“I’d like to understand what’s going on from your side.”

“Is there something getting in the way of being on time?”

“This isn’t about blame—it’s about alignment.”

“Being on time is important for team trust and momentum.”

“Our expectation is that meetings start on time.”

“On time means logged in and ready, not just joining.”

“Let’s figure out a solution that works for you.”

“What would help you arrive a few minutes earlier?”

“Does adjusting your calendar help?”

“Can we agree on this going forward?”

“I appreciate your openness.”

“Let’s reset expectations starting this week.”

“I’ll check back in after the next few meetings.”

“Thanks for taking this seriously.”

“I know you want to set a good example.”

“Let’s stay aligned on this.”
Example Dialogue:
Manager:
“Thanks for meeting with me. I wanted to talk briefly about meeting start times.”

“I’ve noticed you’ve arrived a few minutes late to several meetings over the past couple of weeks.”

“When meetings start late, it disrupts the flow and affects the rest of the team.”

“I want to understand what’s been happening from your side.”

Employee:
“I’ve had back-to-back meetings, and sometimes they run over.”

Manager:
“Thanks for explaining. I understand how that can happen.”

“At the same time, being on time is important for the team and for how we work together.”

“Our expectation is that meetings start on time, with everyone ready to participate.”

“Going forward, what can you do to help make that happen?”

Employee:
“I can block a few minutes between meetings.”

Manager:
“That sounds like a good solution.”

“Let’s agree to start meetings on time from now on.”

“I appreciate you taking this seriously.”

“I’ll check back in after the next few meetings.”
